Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for PC 2010 Conference, Suzhou, China, June 2-5, 2010
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL AND NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT

This award provides partial support for travel of U.S. participants to the 2010 International Symposium on Polymer Chemistry (PC 2010). This meeting will be held in Suzhou, China, June 2 - June 5, 2010. An attendance of 300 is expected including 40 U.S. participants from diverse backgrounds. The technical scope of PC 2010 is intentionally broad to provide a forum that brings together leading and young scientists from academic institutions, governments and industries around the world to discuss the emerging and multi-disciplinary frontiers of polymer science. Five general research areas that encompass the frontiers of polymer chemistry were selected to attract participation from a broad range of disciplines: (1) polymer synthesis, (2) macromolecular architecture and supramolecules, (3) functional polymers for photonics, electronics and optoelectronics, (4) bio-related and medical polymers, (5) structure and characterization of polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Symposium on Polymer Chemistry is an international symposium on polymer chemistry that was initiated and is organized by the State Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry, China. It's goal is to become a platform for intellectual exchange, with an emphisis on polymer chemistry, for polymer scientists from all over the world. Following the  the previous three symposia (Changchun 2004; Dalian 2006 and Hefei 2008), the 4th meeting in the series, PC2010 was held in Suzhou. The University of Massachusetts became involved in the planning of this 4th meeting and raised funds from a number of sources (including NSF, 3M, Henkel, BASF, ACS) to support travel to this meeting. 23 U.S. presentations were made in Suzhou. This was the largest number (by a significant amount) since the inception of the symposium.

The 5th meeting in the series has been planned for Changchun in June, 2012. The symposium will focus on five aspects of polymer chemistry: (1) Polymer Synthesis, (2) Macromolecular Architecture and Supramacromolecules, (3) Functional Polymers, (4) Bio-related and Medical Polymers and (5) Structure and Characterization of Polymers. Tom McCarthy (UMass) is the U.S. Symposium co-Chairman. Geoff Coates (Cornell), Zhibin Guan (UC Irvine), Jim Hedrick (IBM), Tim Long (VT), Coleen Pugh (UAkron), Greg Tew UMass) and Karen Wooley (Texas A&M) are the U.S. representatives on the International Advisory Committee.
